g.text: Materials
place at the atomic nuclei. As such, observed gray level distributions can be utilized as tools to deÔ¨Åne
atomic positions in 2-D.
Another important factor of image formation in transmission microscopes is the thickness of the
specimens. Absorption of electrons in the crystal limits thickness of observed crystal specimens [
Electrons absorption is a function of the applied voltages and results in allowable thicknesses on the
order of nanometers. In the images analyzed in this paper, the thickness of the specimen was on the
order of 10 nm and the number of atomic planes in the specimen was approximately 30. The depth
of focus of the electron microscope was large enough that some 3D features at di
Ô¨Ä
erent depths may
appear in the 2D image [
Another observation concerning the spatial resolution of the 2D image is that in place of utilizing
the spatial resolution predicted by the optical analysis of the microscope, the spatial deÔ¨Ånition criteria
proposed in Reference [
] was adopted. Accordingly, spatial resolution is deÔ¨Åned by the measurable
minimum distances in the HRTEM image plane. The concept of minimum distance requires some
additional explanation. The electron microscope image that was analyzed in this paper [
] was
obtained with an HRTEM JEOL 4000 EX-TEM (JEOL USA Inc., Peabody, MA, USA) operating at
400 KeV [
]. The electron wavelength at this voltage was 0.00193 nm, i.e., on the order of 0.002 nm.
According to the criteria of HRTM[
], with this wavelength of 0.002 nm, one should be able to measure
distances of the order of 0.001 nm. However, the HRTEMJEOL 4000EX-TEMused for recording the
image has a maximumclassical spatial resolution of 0.14 nm[
], two orders of magnitude larger than
the theoretical value. This rating is a consequence of the aberrations of the microscope that lead to the
above calibrated resolution of the microscope. This is the reason that the ‚Äúminimumdistance that can
be measured‚Äù criterion was introduced in Reference [
] as a deÔ¨Ånition for spatial resolution. For the
same reason mentioned in Reference [
], the same criterion was applied in this paper. The bicubic
spline interpolation of the images was utilized to increase the spatial resolution of the images.
3. Methods for Measuring Deformations in Crystals
We will brieÔ¨Çy give a description of the methodology utilized in this study to measure
displacements in crystals caused by applied loads. More details will be given later, while at this point
the main ideas only will be introduced. A detailed description of the applied methods implies a
preceding description of the selected crystal specimen.
In experimental mechanics techniques that measure displacements and derivatives of
displacements, two basic approaches are utilized. One approach is the direct measurements of
distances changes through strain gages methods. The other approach is to apply tagged carriers,
either deterministic or random carriers and through optical means create images of the carriers in
a reference condition, and in a loaded condition. Then, the changes in the Ô¨Åeld are computed by
the di
Ô¨Ä
erence between reference conÔ¨Åguration and loaded conÔ¨Åguration. The scalar Ô¨Åelds of gray
levels are transformed in vectorial Ô¨Åelds corresponding to deformations by either optical correlation
generating fringes in the case of deterministic signals (moir
fringes) or by numerical correlation in the
case of discrete image correlation (DIC).
In the analysis of a crystal, we have a deterministic signal, the crystal structure in the undeformed
condition, and then the deformed structure caused by a loading process. The microscope produces
an image of the atom positions in both conÔ¨Ågurations. It is possible to use also two approaches,
measuring changes of distances in the crystalline conÔ¨Åguration, utilizing basic parameters of the
crystal atoms or a Ô¨Åeld approach applying fringe analysis techniques (for example, [
‚Äì
]). In the
present study, the authors have selected a specimen to analyze a crystal that contained dislocations and
experience deformations under the state of residual stresses produced by the presence of dislocations.
The specimen was a thin crystal wafer of about 10 nmthickness under a state of plane-residual-stresses.
